[[Napoleonic Wars]] |awards=[[Order of the Bath|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] |relations= |laterwork= }} [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] '''Sir Charles Morice Pole, 1st Baronet''' [[Order of the Bath|GCB]] (18 January 1757 – 6 September 1830) was a [[Royal Navy]] officer and colonial governor. As a junior officer he saw action at the [[Siege of Pondicherry (1778)|Siege of Pondicherry]] in [[India]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. After taking command of the fifth-rate [[HMS Success (1781)|HMS ''Success'']] he captured and then destroyed the Spanish frigate [[Spanish ship Santa Catalina|''Santa Catalina'']] in the [[Strait of Gibraltar]] in the [[action of 16 March 1782]] later in that War. After capturing the French privateer [[Vanneau (1782 ship)|''Vanneau'']] in June 1793, Pole took part in the [[Siege of Toulon]] at an early stage of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]]. He went on to be governor and commander-in-chief of [[Colony of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]] and then commanded the Baltic Fleet later in the War. He also served as a [[Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty|Lord Commissioner of the Admiralty]] on the Admiralty Board led by [[Charles Grey, 2nd Earl Grey|Viscount Howick]] during the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. ==Early career== Born the second son of Reginald Pole and Anne Pole (née Buller), Pole was educated at [[Hele's School|Plympton Grammar School]] before joining the [[Royal Naval Academy]] at [[Portsmouth]] in January 1770.{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/22444|title=Sir Charles Pole, 1st Baronet|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=7 April 2015}} He was appointed to the [[fifth-rate]] [[HMS Thames (1758)|HMS ''Thames'']] in 1772 and then transferred to the [[fourth-rate]] [[HMS Salisbury (1769)|HMS ''Salisbury'']] on the [[East Indies Station]] in December 1773.Heathcote, p. 211 Promoted to [[lieutenant]] on 26 June 1777, he was assigned to the [[sixth-rate]] [[HMS Seahorse (1748)|HMS ''Seahorse'']] and then transferred to the fourth-rate [[HMS Rippon (1758)|HMS ''Rippon'']] in 1778 and saw action at the [[Siege of Pondicherry (1778)|Siege of Pondicherry]] in [[India]] in October 1778 during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. He then became commanding officer of the [[sloop]] [[HMS Cormorant (1776)|HMS ''Cormorant'']] and was sent home with the despatches. [[File:HMS Success vs Santa Catalina.jpg|thumb|left|The [[action of 16 March 1782]] at which Pole captured and then destroyed the Spanish frigate [[Spanish ship Santa Catalina|''Santa Catalina'']] in the [[Strait of Gibraltar]]]] Promoted to [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]] on 22 March 1779, Pole became commanding officer of the [[first-rate]] [[HMS Britannia (1762)|HMS ''Britannia'']], flagship of Rear Admiral [[George Darby]], Second-in-Command of the [[Channel Fleet|Channel Squadron]]. He transferred to the command of the sixth-rate [[HMS Hussar (1784)|HMS ''Hussar'']] in 1780 which ran aground off [[Hell Gate]] although he was acquitted at the subsequent [[court-martial]]. He was given command of the fifth-rate [[HMS Success (1781)|HMS ''Success'']] and in her, while undertaking an escort mission in support of the armed store-ship [[HMS Vernon (1781)|HMS ''Vernon'']], captured and then destroyed the Spanish frigate [[Spanish ship Santa Catalina|''Santa Catalina'']] in the [[Strait of Gibraltar]] in the [[action of 16 March 1782]]. Following the end of the War, Pole was given command of the [[third-rate]] [[HMS Crown (1782)|HMS ''Crown'']] before becoming [[Groom of the Chamber|Groom of the Bedchamber]] to the [[William IV of the United Kingdom|Duke of Clarence]] on 1 June 1789.{{LondonGazette|issue=13102|supp=|startpage=417|date=2 June 1789|accessdate=7 April 2015}} He became commanding officer of the fifth-rate [[HMS Melampus (1785)|HMS ''Melampus'']] in 1790, in which he watched the French fleet at [[Brest, France|Brest]], and of the third-rate [[HMS Illustrious (1789)|HMS ''Illustrious'']] in 1791. Pole transferred to the command of the third-rate [[HMS Colossus (1787)|HMS ''Colossus'']] in the [[Mediterranean Fleet]] in early 1793 and, after capturing the French privateer [[Vanneau (1782 ship)|''Vanneau'']] in June 1793, took part in the [[Siege of Toulon]] at an early stage of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]]. ==Senior command== [[File:SirCharlesMoricePole.jpg|thumb|left|Sir Charles Pole, later in his career]] Promoted to [[rear-admiral]] on 1 June 1795, Pole became Second-in-Command of the [[North America and West Indies Station|West Indies Station]] with his flag in HMS ''Colossus''.Heathcote, p. 212 He went on to be [[Captain of the Fleet]] in the [[Channel Fleet|Channel Squadron]] under [[Alexander Hood, 1st Viscount Bridport|Lord Bridport]] in March 1797. It fell to Pole to advise the [[Admiralty]] about the strikes by sailors demanding better pay and conditions which came to be known as the [[Spithead and Nore mutinies|Spithead mutiny]]. Pole returned to [[Spithead]] with negotiators from the Admiralty but talks broke down when Admiral [[Alan Gardner, 1st Baron Gardner|Sir Alan Gardner]] threatened to hang all the mutineers. [[File:Wall Hall.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Wall Hall|Aldenham Abbey]], Pole's house in Hertfordshire]] Pole became governor and commander-in-chief of [[Newfoundland Colony|Newfoundland]] on 3 June 1800: following his appointment he focussed on dealing with a serious outbreak of [[smallpox]] that had taken place, deploying the latest practices in [[inoculation]] and establishing a "Committee for the Relief of the Poor".{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/govhouse/governors/g34.html |title=Sir Charles Pole, 1st Baronet |publisher=Government House, Newfoundland|accessdate=7 April 2015}} Promoted to [[vice-admiral]] on 1 January 1801,{{LondonGazette|issue=15324|supp=|startpage=9|date=30 December 1800|accessdate=7 April 2015}} he became Commander-in-Chief of the Baltic Fleet, with his flag in the [[second-rate]] [[HMS St George (1785)|HMS ''St George'']] in June 1801. Pole was created a [[Pole baronets|baronet]] on 18 August 1801{{LondonGazette|issue=15397|supp=|startpage=1006|date=15 August 1801|accessdate=7 April 2015}} and then became [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Newark (UK Parliament constituency)|Newark]] in 1802. In December 1802 he was asked to chair a commission of naval inquiry into abuses in the civil administration which reported in May 1803. Promoted to full [[admiral]] on 9 November 1805,{{LondonGazette|issue=15859|supp=|startpage=1373|date=5 November 1805|accessdate=7 April 2015}} Pole was present at the funeral of [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Lord Nelson]] in January 1806.{{LondonGazette|issue=15881|supp=|startpage=59|date=14 January 1806|accessdate=7 April 2015}} He became a [[Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty|Lord Commissioner of the Admiralty]] on the Admiralty Board led by [[Charles Grey, 2nd Earl Grey|Viscount Howick]] in February 1806.{{cite web|title=Sainty, JC, ''Lord High Admiral and Commissioners of the Admiralty 1660-1870', Office-Holders in Modern Britain: Volume 4: Admiralty Officials 1660-1870'' (1975), pp. 18-31.|url=http://british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=16652| accessdate =4 September 2009}} He was also elected Member of Parliament for [[Plymouth (UK Parliament constituency)|Plymouth]] in November 1806.{{LondonGazette|issue=15975|supp=|startpage=1496|date=15 November 1806|accessdate=7 April 2015}} However he stood down as a Lord Commissioner when the [[William Cavendish-Bentinck, 3rd Duke of Portland#The Duke of Portland's Second Ministry, March 1807 – October 1809|Second Portland Ministry]] took power in March 1807: in Parliament he became increasingly critical of the new Government particularly in relation to their handling of the [[Battle of Copenhagen (1807)|raid on Copenhagen]] in 1807 (which led to the [[Anglo-Russian War (1807–12)|Anglo-Russian War]]) and the [[Convention of Sintra]] in 1808 (which allowed the French to evacuate their troops from [[Portugal]]). Pole was appointed a [[Order of the Bath|Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] on 12 April 1815{{LondonGazette|issue=17004|supp=|startpage=725|date=18 April 1815|accessdate=7 April 2015}} and advanced to [[Order of the Bath|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] on 20 April 1818.{{LondonGazette|issue=17334|supp=|startpage=352|date=21 February 1818|accessdate=7 April 2015}} He went on to be [[Deputy Governor of the Bank of England]] in 1818{{cite web|url=http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/about/Documents/pdfs/deputygovernors.pdf|title=Deputy Governors|publisher=Bank of England|accessdate=7 April 2015}} and [[Governor of the Bank of England]] in 1820.{{cite web|url=http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/about/Documents/pdfs/governors.pdf|title=Governors|publisher=Bank of England|accessdate=7 April 2015}} He became Sheriff of [[Hertfordshire]] in November 1824,{{LondonGazette|issue=18079|supp=|startpage=1858|date=13 November 1824|accessdate=7 April 2015}} and having been promoted to [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]] on 22 July 1830,{{LondonGazette|issue=18709|supp=|startpage=1539|date=23 July 1830|accessdate=7 April 2015}} he died at his home, [[Wall Hall|Aldenham Abbey]], on 6 September 1830. ==Family== In 1792 Pole married Henrietta Goddard;
